information:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney formally invited Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to the G7 summit scheduled for June 15-17, 2025, in Kananaskis, Alberta. The invitation was extended in March 2025. On May 27, 2025, Zelenskyy confirmed his intention to go, stating to Ukrainian journalists, "G7: I was invited by the Canadian Prime Minister Carney. And I will be." Canadian security planning documents list Zelenskyy among the expected attendees, prompting preparations including a no-fly-zone over the area.

Between 2022 and 2024, Volodymyr Zelenskyy participated in three G7 summits: he attended the 2023 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, in person, and attended the 2022 summit in Elmau, Germany, and the 2024 summit in Apulia, Italy, virtually. Throughout the war, he has made numerous international trips, including visits to Washington, Paris, and Davos. On June 2, 2025, he arrived in Vilnius, Lithuania, to attend the Bucharest Nine summit ahead of the NATO summit scheduled for June 24-25 in The Hague.

A key topic of discussion related to the G7 summit is the potential for new sanctions against Russia. US Senators Lindsey Graham and Richard Blumenthal have advocated for a new package of sanctions to be coordinated with European allies before the summit. However, according to news reports citing EU diplomats, it is unlikely that the European Union will have a new sanctions package ready by mid-June. President Zelenskyy has publicly called for increased pressure on Russia and for joint sanctions to be agreed upon at the G7 level.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 12–14 days, with resolution by June 17, 2025.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: A sudden wartime crisis in Ukraine (e.g., major missile barrages or a breakthrough on the front) compels Zelenskyy to remain in-country; or a late security/health issue or aviation/logistics disruption leads to cancellation or a switch to virtual participation; or an unforeseen venue/security disruption in Canada reduces his in-person role.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Zelenskyy flies to Alberta and attends the G7 leaders’ sessions in Kananaskis, physically interacting with other heads of state, participating in photo-ops and bilateral meetings on-site.
forecast.rationale: Signals strongly favor attendance. According to the assistant’s report, PM Mark Carney formally invited Zelenskyy for June 15–17, 2025; on May 27 Zelenskyy stated publicly he will go; Canadian security planning lists him among expected attendees, with preparations such as a no-fly zone. Zelenskyy is actively traveling internationally this month (e.g., in Vilnius on June 2), and he has a track record of making significant in-person appearances when strategically valuable. The G7 is a prime venue for pushing coordinated Russia sanctions and aid, aligning with his stated goals. These are clear, convergent indicators for a Yes. Why not higher? There remains meaningful tail risk for last-minute cancellations: wartime exigencies could force him to stay, security concerns could elevate, or a health/aircraft/logistics issue could intervene. Precedent also shows variability (virtual participation in 2022 and 2024 G7s). Why not lower? We have explicit commitment from Zelenskyy, host-nation planning that assumes his presence, and strategic incentives to attend in person. What would move me upward: confirmed travel details (departure/flight tracking), official Canadian/Ukrainian schedules with on-site bilaterals, his arrival in North America, and stable conditions in Ukraine in the days prior. What would move me downward: credible reports of a major surge in Russian attacks or a domestic emergency, official guidance that he will participate virtually, indications of security concerns specific to Kananaskis, or reports of illness/transport issues.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Volodymyr Zelenskyy attend the G7 Summit in June 2025?

Question background:
Calgary Herald: [Prime Minister Carney invites Ukrainian President Zelenskyy to G7 summit in Kananaskis](https://calgaryherald.com/news/local-news/pm-mark-carney-invites-ukrainian-president-volodymyr-zelenskyy-g7-summit-kananaskis)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Ukrainian President Volodymyr Oleksandrovych Zelenskyy attends in person a G7 summit held in June 2025.

"In person" is defined as occupying the same physical space closely enough at the G7 Summit that he can see and hear other heads of state through direct un-intermediated exchange of photons and sound waves.


Your research assistant's report says:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney formally invited Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to the G7 summit scheduled for June 15-17, 2025, in Kananaskis, Alberta. The invitation was extended in March 2025. On May 27, 2025, Zelenskyy confirmed his intention to go, stating to Ukrainian journalists, "G7: I was invited by the Canadian Prime Minister Carney. And I will be." Canadian security planning documents list Zelenskyy among the expected attendees, prompting preparations including a no-fly-zone over the area.

Between 2022 and 2024, Volodymyr Zelenskyy participated in three G7 summits: he attended the 2023 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, in person, and attended the 2022 summit in Elmau, Germany, and the 2024 summit in Apulia, Italy, virtually. Throughout the war, he has made numerous international trips, including visits to Washington, Paris, and Davos. On June 2, 2025, he arrived in Vilnius, Lithuania, to attend the Bucharest Nine summit ahead of the NATO summit scheduled for June 24-25 in The Hague.

A key topic of discussion related to the G7 summit is the potential for new sanctions against Russia. US Senators Lindsey Graham and Richard Blumenthal have advocated for a new package of sanctions to be coordinated with European allies before the summit. However, according to news reports citing EU diplomats, it is unlikely that the European Union will have a new sanctions package ready by mid-June. President Zelenskyy has publicly called for increased pressure on Russia and for joint sanctions to be agreed upon at the G7 level.

Today is 2025-06-03.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
